Ovid was born¹ at Sulmo, now Sulmona‚ a chief town of the Paeligni, who were a branch of the great Samnite stock. The town lay some ninety miles² east of Rome, amongst the Apennines, in a district famous for its corn and vines and olives, and where the air was fresh, and the streams abundant, even in the hottest part of the year.8 The day of his birth was March 20th, 43 B.c. It was a memorable date in Roman history, for upon that day was fought the battle of Mutina, in which the consuls Hirtius and Pansa defeated Mark Antony indeed, but lost their lives⁴ in the victory.
